name: Bowline (Palstek)

visual.attribution: Video by PhilEOS, CC BY-SA 3.0, via Wikimedia Commons

description: Creates a reliable fixed loop at the end of a rope. Known as the 'King of Knots'.

details.easeOfUntying: Relatively easy, even after heavy load.
details.securityNote: Can shake loose if unloaded; consider backup/stopper knot for critical applications.

cons: Can potentially shake loose if not under load.
Cannot be tied/untied when weighted.
Lower breaking strength compared to Figure Eight loop.
applications: Rescue, mooring boats, attaching rope to objects, general utility loop.

name: Square Knot (Reef Knot)
description: A simple knot for joining two ropes of *equal* thickness or for binding.

details.easeOfUntying: Can jam badly after moderate loading.
details.securityNote: **Unsafe for critical loads.** Prone to capsizing or slipping, especially with synthetic ropes.

pros: Very simple and quick to tie.
cons: Unreliable and unsafe for critical loads.
Can capsize or slip easily.
Jams tightly.
applications: Tying bandages, securing parcels (non-critical), reefing sails (its namesake). **Avoid for safety applications.**

name: Clove Hitch
description: Fastens a rope to a post, rail, or carabiner.

details.easeOfUntying: Can bind, moderately difficult after heavy load.
details.securityNote: Can slip under cyclical loads or vibrations; often requires backup (e.g., half-hitch).

pros: Quick and easy to tie, even one-handed.
Can be tied mid-rope or at the end.
cons: Can slip, especially on smooth surfaces or with vibrations.
Can bind.
applications: Temporary moorings, starting lashings, tent guylines (with backup), attaching to carabiners (climbing anchors - adjustable).

name: Figure-Eight Knot / Follow-Through
description: Fundamental knot used as a stopper or tied back on itself (follow-through) for a strong loop.

details.strengthImpact: Low reduction (Loop: ~20-25%). Strongest common end loop.
details.easeOfUntying: Moderately difficult after very heavy load, but better than Overhand.
details.securityNote: Very secure and reliable loop. Easy to visually inspect for correctness.

pros: Good stopper knot (less prone to jamming than Overhand).
cons: Bulkier than some alternatives (Bowline, Overhand).
Can be harder to untie after extreme loading than a Bowline.
applications:
Stopper: Preventing rope end passing through device.
Loop: Standard for climbing harnesses, rescue, critical load attachment.

name: Sheet Bend
description: Joins two ropes, especially of unequal thickness. Working ends must be on the *same* side.

details.securityNote: Less secure than Figure Eight Bend or Double Fisherman's. Can work loose if not under tension. Double Sheet Bend is more secure.

pros: Effective for joining ropes of different diameters/materials.
cons: Not for critical loads.
Can slip if not kept taut.
Less secure than other bends.
applications: Joining flags to halyards, extending ropes temporarily, net making, general utility (non-critical).

name: Taut-Line Hitch
description: Creates an adjustable loop or attaches to an object, allowing the line to be tightened. (Midshipman's Hitch often preferred).

details.securityNote: Can slip on very slick ropes or if not dressed properly. Test under load.

cons: Can slip if tied incorrectly or with very slick ropes.
Less secure than fixed loops for critical loads.
applications: Tent guylines, clotheslines, securing tarps, adjustable load securing (non-critical).

name: Two Half-Hitches
description: Very simple hitch for temporarily securing a rope to a post or ring.

details.securityNote: Not secure for important loads. Can slip easily. Often needs additional hitches or backup.

pros: Extremely easy and quick to tie.
cons: Not very secure; slips easily.
Can bind.
Unsuitable for critical applications.
applications: Temporary fastening of light loads, brief mooring (very light boat), clotheslines (may slip).

name: Overhand Knot
description: The simplest knot, basis for many others. Used primarily as a basic stopper.

details.easeOfUntying: Jams very badly after loading; often impossible to untie.
details.securityNote: Weakest stopper knot. Can roll off the end under load. Avoid for critical uses.

cons: Jams very tightly.
Weakens the rope significantly.
Can roll/fail under load.
applications: Simple non-critical stopper, temporary knot, base for other knots (e.g., Water Knot, Fisherman's Knot).

name: Alpine Butterfly Loop
description: Forms a secure, stable loop in the middle of a rope.

details.securityNote: Very reliable when tied correctly. Loadable in 3 directions.

pros: Strong and stable loop, loadable in three directions.
Can be tied in the bight (mid-rope).
cons: Slightly more complex to learn than Bowline/Figure Eight.
Can be visually confusing to inspect if unfamiliar.
applications: Climbing (isolating rope damage, mid-rope anchors, glacier travel), rescue, creating fixed loops along a line.

name: Double Fisherman's Bend
description: Very strong and secure method for joining two ropes, especially similar-diameter synthetic ropes.

details.strengthImpact: Low reduction (~20-30%). One of the strongest bends.
details.securityNote: Very reliable for critical joins. Ensure sufficient tail length.

cons: Considered permanent after heavy loading.
Can be difficult to tie correctly; requires careful dressing.
applications: Joining climbing ropes (rappelling), making cordelettes/prusik loops, critical/permanent rope joining.

name: Prusik Knot
description: A friction hitch tied with a loop of cord around a thicker rope. Grips when loaded, slides when unloaded.

details.strengthImpact: Does not weaken the main rope; relies on strength of cord loop.
details.easeOfUntying: Usually easy, can jam slightly after very heavy load.
details.securityNote: Requires correct cord diameter ratio (typically ~60-80% of main rope). Can slip on wet/icy ropes. Test function before critical use.

pros: Grips well in both directions along the main rope.
Can be slid along the rope when not weighted.
cons: Requires a pre-tied loop of appropriate cord.
Can jam after heavy load cycles.
May slip on wet/icy ropes. Other friction hitches may perform better.
applications: Climbing (ascending ropes, progress capture, rappel backup - use caution), rescue, arborist work.

name: Trucker's Hitch
description: Compound knot system providing mechanical advantage (typically 3:1) to tighten a line securely.

details.strengthImpact: Variable; limited by the strength of the loop knot used and friction point.
details.easeOfUntying: Relatively easy to release tension; loop knot might jam.
details.securityNote: Reliability depends heavily on the loop knot used (e.g., avoid Slippery Half Hitch for loop). Rope can wear at friction point.

cons: More complex than simple hitches.
Strength/reliability depends on loop choice.
Can cause high friction and rope wear.
applications: Securing loads on trucks/trailers/racks, creating high-tension ridgelines, clotheslines, general load securing.

name: Rolling Hitch
description: A friction hitch used to attach a rope to another rope, pole, or cable, especially for pulling along the object.

details.securityNote: Grips securely when pulled in line with the standing part (direction of the turns). May slip if pulled sideways or on very slick surfaces.

pros: Grips well when pulled in one direction along the object.
Can be slid along the object when slack.
cons: Less secure if the pull is not aligned correctly.
May slip on very smooth or tapered objects.
applications: Creating adjustable snubbers on mooring lines, attaching a rope to a taut line (e.g., anchor rode), hauling along a fixed line, backup for other hitches.
